content.question: Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></math> are at rest on a horizontal surface. Object <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is in contact with object <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The force diagrams for both objects are shown above. Which two forces make up an action-reaction pair?

choices.label: <math alttext="F sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mtext></mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because both forces are exerted on different objects, have the same magnitude, and are in opposite directions.

<math alttext="F sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, because both forces are exerted on the same object, have the same magnitude, and are in opposite directions.

<math alttext="F sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub 5" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, because both forces are exerted on different objects, have the same magnitude, and are in the same direction.

<math alttext="F sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, because both forces are exerted on different objects, have the same magnitude, and are in opposite directions.

content.answer: <math alttext="F sub 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="F sub 6" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>6</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, because both forces are exerted on different objects, have the same magnitude, and are in opposite directions.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
